light source.context: Artificial photoreduction of CO 2 to chemical fuel is an intriguing and reliable strategy to tackle the issues of energy crisis and climate change simultaneously.In the present study, we rationally constructed a Ni (OH) 2 -modified covalent triazine-based framework (CTF-1) composites to serve as cocatalyst ensemble for superior photoreduction of CO 2 .In particular, the optimal Ni(OH) 2 -CTF-1 composites (loading ratio at 0.5 wt) exhibited superior photocatalytic activity, which surpassed the bare CTF-1 by 33 times when irradiated by visible light.The mechanism for the enhancement was systematically investigated based on various instrumental analyses.The origin of the superior activity was attributable to the enhanced CO 2 capture, more robust visible-light response, and improved charge carrier separation/transfer.This study offers an innovative pathway for the fabrication of noble-metal-free cocatalysts on CTF semiconductors and deepens the understanding of photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.

light source.context: In summary, we rationally constructed the Ni(OH) 2 nanoparticles loaded on CTF-1 as cocatalysts by a facile precipitation process.The cocatalyst-semiconductor interfacial interaction provided an efficient conductive path for photoinduced electrons from CTF-1 to Ni(OH) 2 and thus leading to boosting photoreduction of CO 2 .Compared with bulk CTF-1, the Ni(OH) 2 -CTF-1 samples showed remarkable improvement and the sample with the loading ratio of 0.5 wt exhibited an optimum CO evolution rate, corresponding to 38.66 mmol h A1 g A1 .The superiority of the as-prepared sample was assigned to efficient charge carriers separation/transfer after the modification of Ni(OH) 2 .Moreover, the introduction of Ni (OH) 2 nanoparticles could result in increased specific surface area, improved CO 2 adsorption and enhanced visible light absorption.Compared with previous works where noble-and/or rare-metal compounds were used as cocatalysts 29303132, this work showcases that the earth-abundant metal hydroxide, that is, Ni(OH) 2 may serve as a good additive to boost the photocatalytic activity.The Fig. 1.Illustration of the preparation route for CTF-1 and Ni(OH) 2 /CTF-1 composites. reaction medium.context: All chemicals and reagents were analytical reagent (AR) grade without further purification and obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd.The synthetic procedure for CTF-1 was in accordance with our previous report 26.In brief, 10 mL Trifluoromethanesulfonic acid was slowly introduced into 1.28 g 1,4dicyanobenzene in a flask with continuous stirring at 0C.The obtained solution was then kept at 30C for 3 d, and then rinsed by dichloromethane and NH 3 AH 2 O solution (50 vol), respectively.The resulted product was collected and dispersed into NH 3 AH 2 O solution (50 vol) under stirring.After repeatedly washing with distilled water and methanol, the precipitate was refluxed by methanol and dichloromethane for 12 h, respectively, and vacuum-dried at 80C for 12 h.Finally, the light yellow solid was ground to obtain CTF-1. The Ni(OH) 2 was deposited on CTF-1 via a facile precipitation process.Typically, the prepared CTF-1 powders (0.2 g) were evenly suspended in ultrapure water (20 mL), then a certain amount of 10 mg/mL NiCl 2 solution (20 mL, 100 mL, 200 mL, and 400 mL) was progressively added under stirring, respectively.After 1.5 h, a solution with an excess amount of NaOH was instilled.Then the mixed solution underwent vigorous stirring at room temperature for another 6 h.Subsequently, the sample was collected by centrifugation, and repeatedly washed with distilled water and ethanol.Finally, the resultant precipitates were dried at 80C.The obtained samples were denoted as Ni 0.1 -CTF-1, Ni 0.5 -CTF-1, Ni 1 -CTF-1, and Ni 2 -CTF-1, representing the various loading ratio of 0.1, 0.5, 1, and 2 wt, respectively.The preparation route for the samples is presented in Fig. 1. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of the samples were obtained using a Nova Nano SEM 230 microscopy (FEI Corp.) and a TECNAI G2 F20 TEM (FEI Corp.), respectively.The pore volumes were recorded with an ASAP 2020 apparatus (Micromeritics Instrument Corp.) and the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was used to calculate the specific surface areas (S BET ).Powder X-ray diffraction patterns (PXRD) of the samples were performed on a Rigaku MiniFlex 600 X-ray diffractometer with Ni-filtered Cu Kairradiation (a 1.5406 A).The 2h range was set from 5 to 80.Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) analyses of the samples were conducted on a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS10 spectrometer using KBr pellets at a resolution of 4 cm A1 .X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra of the samples were recorded on a PHI Quantum 2000 XPS system equipped with a monochromatic Al Ka X-ray source.The C 1s peak (284.6 eV) of the surface adventitious were referenced as standard binding energy.The solid-state UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra (UV-vis DRS) were carried out on a Varian Cary 500 Scan UV-vis-NIR spectrophotometer.The photoluminescence (PL) spectra were recorded using an Edinburgh FL/FS 900 spectrophotometer with the excitation wavelength set at 420 nm.Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted on a NETZSCH STA 449C thermogravimetric analyzer with the heating rate set as 10C/min. The photocurrent analyses and Mott-Schottky tests were obtained via an electrochemical system (CHI 650E, Shanghai Chenhua Instrument Co. Ltd.China) equipped with a standard three-electrode system.A 0.2 M Na 2 SO 4 solution was used as electrolyte.An Ag/AgCl electrode and a platinum plate electrode were used as the reference electrode and counter electrode, respectively.The working electrode was prepared according to our previous report.Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) plots of the samples were obtained using a Zahner PP211 electrochemical workstation with a 10 mM K 3 Fe(CN) 6 /0.1 M KCl mixed aqueous solution as electrolyte. The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction experiments were performed in a closed reactor.A 300 W Xenon lamp with a 420 nm cut-off filter was used as the light source.In a typical experiment, 10 mg of the as-prepared sample and 7 mg photosensitizer Ru(bpy) 3 Cl 2 -A6H 2 O were dispersed in the reactor containing a solution of triethanolamine (TEOA)/distilled water/acetonitrile (150 mL/300 mL/450 mL).Then the reaction mixture was subjected to continuous magnetic stirring.Prior to illumination, the gas in the reactor was evacuated by a vacuum pump for 2 min and then filled with CO 2 for 20 min.After illumination for 4 h, 400 mL of the gas was sampled with a syringe and then injected into a gas chromatography (GC-7890B) for the measurement of CH 4 and CO.Three consecutive photocatalytic CO 2 reduction cycles were conducted to verify the stability of Ni(OH) 2 -CTF-1.After the first photocatalytic CO 2 reduction, Ni 0.5 -CTF-1 photocatalyst was centrifuged by deionized water and ethanol for several times, respectively, then dried at 80C overnight.The afresh obtained Ni 0.5 -CTF-1 was used for the following photocatalytic CO 2 reduction under the same experimental condition.
